thread.title: New pro league eyes Alamodome
thread.title_full: New pro football league eyes Alamodome - San Antonio Express-News

author: Tom Orsborn
title: New pro league eyes Alamodome
text:
Photo: William Luther /San Antonio Express-News Image 1 of / 21 21 Texas Coyote football players enter the field June 15, 2002 at a virtually-empty Comalander Stadium. Fans sat on only one side of the stadium for the North American Football League franchise’s home opener.
Photo: William Luther /San Antonio Express-News Texas Coyote football players enter the field June 15, 2002 at a... Image 2 of 21 Click through the slideshow to see what the Alamodome needs to do to become a top-flight stadium.
Photo: © 2012 San Antonio Express-News Click through the slideshow to see what the Alamodome needs to do... Image 3 of 21 1. Natural light/retractable roof.
The Alamodome can be described as "cavernous" and "dingy," and the basic interior structure does basically resemble the inside of a closed box. Since the dome does bid on the Final Four and host large concerts, cutting a hole in the roof may be out of the question, but a retractable roof made of a material that lets in light would brighten things up considerably.
Photo: Ronald Martinez, Getty Images 1. Natural light/retractable roof.
The Alamodome can be described as... Image 4 of 21 NRG (Reliant) Stadium 's retractable roof — though rarely opened — still lets in plenty of natural light even when closed. You have to admit that this open-air look does make for a better fan experience.
Photo: DAVID J. PHILLIP, AP NRG (Reliant) Stadium 's retractable roof — though rarely opened... Image 5 of 21 2. Bigger video boards
The Alamodome features two 24 ft. by 32 ft. video "walls," according to the dome's website. In today's sports stadium landscape that is tiny, and is about as useful as an old tube television set. We are already way behind the times in this area and need to go big.
Photo: Kin Man Hui /San Antonio Express-News 2. Bigger video boards
The Alamodome features two 24 ft. by 32 ft.... Image 6 of 21 Maybe not as big as the new 362 ft. by 50 ft. video board at Everbank Field in Jacksonville, Florida (yes, that "Hit Squad" thing is a giant video board), but we can still size up considerably. This board is so big — well, wide — that it clowns the famous video screen at Dallas' AT&T Stadium that is 72 ft. by 160 ft.
Photo: Stacy Revere, Getty Images Maybe not as big as the new 362 ft. by 50 ft. video board at. .. Image 7 of 21 3. Flawless, natural turf
Let's avoid the disaster that happened in April when the U.S. Men's National Team faced off against Mexico. That game was supposed to make San Antonio look like a phenomenal soccer city and instead the condition of the awful pitch — which was visible even on TV — was so bad that we may never host a national team soccer game again.
3. Flawless, natural turf
Let's avoid the disaster that happened in... Image 8 of 21 At the University of Phoenix Stadium in Arizona, they keep the field in one piece and just roll it out from time to time to get some sun. But if the Alamodome got a retractable roof they could just open the roof up to get the field some light.
Photo: Charlie Riedel, AP At the University of Phoenix Stadium in Arizona, they keep the... Image 9 of 21 4. Upgraded luxury executive suites (and add more of them)
The Alamodome currently has "52 luxury, newly furnished and renovated, club level, suites for the ultimate viewing and entertainment experience," according to the website. As you can see by this photo, which is reflective of what is on the Alamodome website, these "luxury" suites are not up to the modern standard.
Photo: Bob Owen, San Antonio Express-News 4. Upgraded luxury executive suites (and add more of them)
The... Image 10 of 21 This is a newly renovated luxury suite at the Carolina Panthers' Bank of America stadium on July 14, 2015. The Panthers renovated all of their 157 suites during the off season. At Levi's Stadium, the 49ers new home field, there are 170 suites.
Photo: Chuck Burton, AP This is a newly renovated luxury suite at the Carolina Panthers'... Image 11 of 21 5. Bold color scheme
The blue seats at the Alamodome do go well with the UTSA Roadrunners' official shade of blue and the secondary orange, but with all the grey cement it all appears washed out. Lets make all the seats orange, which would really pop under the natural light from the new retractable roof.
Photo: Ronald Martinez, Getty Images 5. Bold color scheme
The blue seats at the Alamodome do go well with... Image 12 of 21 The Kansas City Chiefs' Arrowhead Stadium is one of the loudest stadiums in the NFL, and the atmosphere is boosted by the colorful red and yellow seats. The Pittsburg Steelers' Heinz Field offers the same sort of electric environment with their bold yellow.
Photo: Getty Images The Kansas City Chiefs' Arrowhead Stadium is one of the loudest... Image 13 of 21 6. Comfy new seats
Nobody likes sitting in hard, plastic seats and every fan knows a seat with even minimal padding makes the experience a lot more enjoyable.
Photo: iaguirre@express-news.net 6. Comfy new seats
Nobody likes sitting in hard, plastic seats and... Image 14 of 21 At the renovated Sun Life Stadium , which is home to the Miami Dolphins, every seat has been replaced and suites and bathrooms have been redesigned.
Photo: Steve Wine, AP At the renovated Sun Life Stadium , which is home to the Miami... Image 15 of 21 7. A downtown view
With an excellent downtown location and Tower of the Americas only a stone's throw away, why not find some way to make it all visible from inside.
Photo: JERRY LARA, SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS-NEWS 7. A downtown view
With an excellent downtown location and Tower of... Image 16 of 21 At the Indianapolis Colts' Lucas Oil Stadium , the downtown skyline is visible thanks to huge, glass windows at the end that also let in a good amount of natural light.
Photo: Joe Robbins, Getty Images At the Indianapolis Colts' Lucas Oil Stadium , the downtown skyline... Image 17 of 21 8. Cabana huts and pools
Yeah!!! Woo Hoo!!! Go Roadrunners!!! This one may be a little out there, but as exciting as it is to be cheering from way up here in the stands, you could be doing it from a pool. Yes, there are pools at NFL stadiums with a lovely view of the playing field.
8. Cabana huts and pools
Yeah!!! Woo Hoo!!! Go Roadrunners!!! This... Image 18 of 21 At Everbank Field in Jacksonville, Florida , you can watch the game from the pool or one of the luxury poolside cabanas.
Photo: Don Juan Moore, Getty Images At Everbank Field in Jacksonville, Florida , you can watch the game... Image 19 of 21 9. Solar panels
Having a clean energy source on site would be a great selling point to attract high-profile events. And with plenty of sunshine year-round it would definitely help with the electric bill. San Antonio is already one of the leading cities for solar energy in the U.S. , so why not make this a feature on our signature stadium?
Photo: Express-News File Photo 9. Solar panels
Having a clean energy source on site would be a... Image 20 of 21 At the San Francisco 49ers' new Levi's Stadium, there are solar panels on top of the luxury boxes, known as the Solar Terrace. This NRG-powered renewable energy plan for Levi's can generate enough power in a year to meet electricity demand during every 49ers home game.
Photo: David Coleman, NRG Solar At the San Francisco 49ers' new Levi's Stadium, there are solar... Image 21 of 21 New pro football league eyes Alamodome 1 / 21 Back to Gallery A new professional football league scheduled to begin play in 2016 has contacted the city about leasing the Alamodome , the San Antonio Express-News has learned.
Mike Sawaya , the city official who oversees the dome, said there has been “preliminary discussions” with Major League Football but “no decisions have been made.”
According to its website, MLFB is a “publicly traded, single-entity league” that is the “product of over seven years of planning by former NFL general managers, coaches, players, personnel executives and businessmen that has a singular goal to bring professional football to the public during the spring and early summer of 2016.”
MLFB’s chief executive officer is Jerry Vainisi, formerly GM of the Chicago Bears and vice president of player personnel with the Detroit Lions . Vainisi helped launch NFL Europe more than 20 years ago.
The president of the MLFB is former NFL wide receiver Wes Chandler , who told the Orlando Sentinel in January the idea for the league was hatched seven years ago when he was an assistant coach with the Cleveland Browns .
“There are a lot of people on the street today, both players and coaches, that can still play but need a little bit more growth,” Chandler told the newspaper.
For more, go to ExpressNews.com
torsborn@express-news.net
